name: Food affordability (World Bank; FAO, 2022)
title: Food affordability (World Bank; FAO, 2022)
description:
This variable is sourced from the Food Prices for Nutrition DataHub (https://www.worldbank.org/en/programs/icp/brief/foodpricesfornutrition) and its associated DataBank (https://databank.worldbank.org/source/food-prices-for-nutrition).

The dataset is based on the methodology developed in Herforth et al. (2022), which is a background paper for the UN agencies’ annual report on The State of Food Security and Nutrition in the World 2022 (https://www.fao.org/publications/sofi). It is based on data on prices for locally available food items from the World Bank's International Comparison Program (ICP) (https://icp.worldbank.org) matched to other data on food composition and dietary requirements.

The nutritional requirements used in this study are in line with the WHO's recommendations for the median woman of reproductive age. The authors note two key two reasons for this:

(1) Requirements fall roughly at the median of the entire population distribution, in the sense that least-cost diets to meet energy and nutrient requirements for people in this reference group approximate the median level of least costs for all sex-age groups over the entire life cycle. This reference group is therefore a good representation of the population as a whole.

(2) Women of reproductive age are typically a nutritionally vulnerable population group, as seen in their increased risk of dietary inadequacies (due to social practices and norms that often disadvantage them in terms of access to food), which have important consequences for themselves and their children. Previous studies have also based their analyses on this reference group.

sources.name: Food affordability (World Bank; FAO, 2022)
sources.additionalInfo:
This variable is sourced from the Food Prices for Nutrition DataHub (https://www.worldbank.org/en/programs/icp/brief/foodpricesfornutrition) and its associated DataBank (https://databank.worldbank.org/source/food-prices-for-nutrition).

The dataset is based on the methodology developed in Herforth et al. (2022), which is a background paper for the UN agencies’ annual report on The State of Food Security and Nutrition in the World 2022 (https://www.fao.org/publications/sofi). It is based on data on prices for locally available food items from the World Bank's International Comparison Program (ICP) (https://icp.worldbank.org) matched to other data on food composition and dietary requirements.

The nutritional requirements used in this study are in line with the WHO's recommendations for the median woman of reproductive age. The authors note two key two reasons for this:

(1) Requirements fall roughly at the median of the entire population distribution, in the sense that least-cost diets to meet energy and nutrient requirements for people in this reference group approximate the median level of least costs for all sex-age groups over the entire life cycle. This reference group is therefore a good representation of the population as a whole.

(2) Women of reproductive age are typically a nutritionally vulnerable population group, as seen in their increased risk of dietary inadequacies (due to social practices and norms that often disadvantage them in terms of access to food), which have important consequences for themselves and their children. Previous studies have also based their analyses on this reference group.
sources.dataPublishedBy: Food Prices for Nutrition data at the World Bank, based on Herforth, Venkat, Bai, Costlow, Holleman & Masters (2022).

fields.name: cost_energy_sufficient_diet
fields.description:
The cost of an energy sufficient diet (CoCA) is defined as the minimum cost to meet energy
requirements using the least-cost available starchy staple food in each country.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Cost of a calorie sufficient diet", "unit": "2017 USD per day", "shortUnit": "$", "includeInTable": true}

fields.name: cost_energy_sufficient_relative_expenditure
fields.description:
The cost of an energy sufficient diet (CoCA) is defined as the minimum cost to meet energy
requirements using the least-cost available starchy staple food in each country.

This is given as a percentage of the average national expenditure on food.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Cost of a calorie sufficient diet as a share of average food expenditure", "unit": "%", "shortUnit": "%", "includeInTable": true}

fields.name: cost_healthy_diet
fields.description: The cost of a healthy diet (CoHD) is defined as the lowest-cost set of items available at each time and place that would meet requirements for each food group specified in food-based dietary guidelines (FBDGs). Food-based dietary guidelines come from national governments or public health agencies. The global CoHD is based on commonalities among all guidelines, using the least expensive locally available foods to maintain energy balance and dietary diversity across 11 items in 6 food groups.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Cost of a healthy diet", "unit": "2017 USD per day", "shortUnit": "$", "includeInTable": true, "numDecimalPlaces": 2}

fields.name: cost_healthy_relative_expenditure
fields.description:
The cost of a healthy diet (CoHD) is defined as the lowest-cost set of items available at each time and place that would meet requirements for each food group specified in food-based dietary guidelines (FBDGs). Food-based dietary guidelines come from national governments or public health agencies. The global CoHD is based on commonalities among all guidelines, using the least expensive locally available foods to maintain energy balance and dietary diversity across 11 items in 6 food groups.

This cost is given as a percentage of the national average food expenditure.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Cost of a healthy diet as a share of average expenditure on food", "unit": "%", "shortUnit": "%", "includeInTable": true}

fields.name: cost_nutrient_sufficient_diet
fields.description:
The cost of a nutrient adequate diet (CoNA) is defined as the lowest-cost set of items available
at each time and place that would stay within the lower and upper bounds for dietary energy
and all essential nutrients. Operationally, the CoNA is measured as the minimum cost to
meet EER and relevant daily nutrient reference values of 23 macro- and micronutrients for
a representative person in a reference population.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Cost of a nutritionally adequate diet", "unit": "2017 USD per day", "shortUnit": "$", "includeInTable": true, "numDecimalPlaces": 2}

fields.name: cost_nutrient_sufficient_relative_expenditure
fields.description:
The lowest-cost nutritionally adequate diet as a share of average national food expenditure.

The cost of a nutrient adequate diet (CoNA) is defined as the lowest-cost set of items available
at each time and place that would stay within the lower and upper bounds for dietary energy
and all essential nutrients. Operationally, the CoNA is measured as the minimum cost to
meet EER and relevant daily nutrient reference values of 23 macro- and micronutrients for
a representative person in a reference population.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Cost of nutritionally adequate diet as a share of average food expenditure", "unit": "%", "shortUnit": "%", "includeInTable": true}

fields.name: energy_sufficient_unaffordable_number
fields.description:
A diet is deemed unaffordable if it costs more than 52% of a household's income.

The cost of an energy sufficient diet (CoCA) is defined as the minimum cost to meet energy
requirements using the least-cost available starchy staple food in each country.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Number of people that cannot afford a calorie sufficient diet", "unit": "people", "shortUnit": "", "includeInTable": true, "conversionFactor": 1000000, "numDecimalPlaces": 0}

fields.name: energy_sufficient_unaffordable_share
fields.description:
A diet is deemed unaffordable if it costs more than 52% of a household's income.

The cost of an energy sufficient diet (CoCA) is defined as the minimum cost to meet energy
requirements using the least-cost available starchy staple food in each country.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Share of population that cannot afford a calorie sufficient diet", "unit": "%", "shortUnit": "%", "includeInTable": true}

fields.name: healthy_unaffordable_number
fields.description:
The cost of a healthy diet (CoHD) is defined as the lowest-cost set of items available at each time and place that would meet requirements for each food group specified in food-based dietary guidelines (FBDGs). Food-based dietary guidelines come from national governments or public health agencies. The global CoHD is based on commonalities among all guidelines, using the least expensive locally available foods to maintain energy balance and dietary diversity across 11 items in 6 food groups.

A diet is deemed unaffordable if it costs more than 52% of a household's income.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Number of people that cannot afford a healthy diet", "unit": "people", "includeInTable": true, "conversionFactor": 1000000, "numDecimalPlaces": 0}

fields.name: nutrition_sufficient_unaffordable_number
fields.description:
A diet is deemed unaffordable if it costs more than 52% of a household's income.

The cost of a nutrient adequate diet (CoNA) is defined as the lowest-cost set of items available at each time and place that would stay within the lower and upper bounds for dietary energy and all essential nutrients. Operationally, the CoNA is measured as the minimum cost to
meet EER and relevant daily nutrient reference values of 23 macro- and micronutrients for
a representative person in a reference population.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Number that cannot afford a nutritionally adequate diet", "unit": "people", "shortUnit": "", "includeInTable": true, "conversionFactor": 1000000, "numDecimalPlaces": 0}

fields.name: nutrition_sufficient_unaffordable_share
fields.description:
A diet is deemed unaffordable if it costs more than 52% of a household's income.

The cost of a healthy diet (CoRD) is defined as the lowest-cost set of items available at each time and place that would meet requirements for each food group specified in food-based dietary guidelines (FBDGs). Food-based dietary guidelines come from national governments or public health agencies, and are defined based on regionally representative guidelines.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Share of population that cannot afford a nutritionally adequate diet", "unit": "%", "shortUnit": "%", "includeInTable": true}

fields.name: healthy_unaffordable_share
fields.description:
A diet is deemed unaffordable if it costs more than 52% of a household's income.

The cost of a healthy diet (CoHD) is defined as the lowest-cost set of items available at each time and place that would meet requirements for each food group specified in food-based dietary guidelines (FBDGs). Food-based dietary guidelines come from national governments or public health agencies. The global CoHD is based on commonalities among all guidelines, using the least expensive locally available foods to maintain energy balance and dietary diversity across 11 items in 6 food groups.
fields.owidDisplaySettings: {"name": "Share of population that cannot afford a healthy diet", "unit": "%", "shortUnit": "%", "includeInTable": true}
